Deficits probable in near future
By ALAN HIRSCH
After four years of balanced
budgets, Hopkins officials are
anticipating several years of
budget deficits, beginning with
the next fiscal year.
President Muller said earlier
this week that he is probably
going to present a deficit budget
to the Board of Trustees for the
1976-1977 fiscal year as well as
in succeeding years.
"We are beginning to look now
at the budget for 1976-77. For
the first time since I've been
President, we cannot anticipate
increased sources of imcome
except in tuition," Muller stated.
"We'll be very lucky if we
sustain the income we have," he
added.
The increased revenues will be
needed to meet rising
expenditures, particularly in the
areas of salaries, utilities, postage,
and paper, Muller said.
"We have already made some
fairly extensive cuts in

expenditures," he continued. "It
is not likely that in Arts and
Sciences we can make huge new
economies."
Deficit
Muller also revealed that the
University could run a deficit
this year if oil prices are raised
within the next few months and
if the winter is a severe one.
Even though expenditures
began to rise sharply before this
year, the University was able to
meet rising costs without
constant rises in tuition because
of an influx of money from
unexpected sources, such as State
assistance, increased endowment
.yield, indirect cost recoveries,
and clinical fees from doctors at
the Medical Institutions, Muller
explained.
What Muller termed as "model
fiscal management" in the past
several years has also helped meet
rising costs.

CHIP to improve schooling of sick students
By RUSS SMITH
Almost sixty Baltimore school
children who are plagued with
chronic illnesses are now
receiving an expanded program
of home and hospital teaching
during their absence from school.
The Chronic Health Impaired
Program (CHIP), directed by
Frances Bateson and Mrs. Nancy
Rini, serves local grade school
students who suffer from
ailments such as diabetes,
asthma, and heart disorders.
Assistance
Previously, only children who
were absent from school for six
weeks or more were eligible for
educational assistance in the
home or hospital. Those with
errant health problems often
missed a substantial portion of
the school year, though each
illness was not long enough to
qualify the student for home
teaching.

CHIP, which started this
month, was conceived by the
Area for Exceptional Children, a
division of the Baltimore City
Public Schools. Financed by local
educational funds, the program is
open to those who attend both
public and private facilities. The
sole stipulation is that the child's
parents reside in Baltimore.
Students with chronic illnesses
are referred to CHIP by health
agencies, hospitals, and
pediatricians.
The staff of 28 qualified
teachers, in addition to a pool of
two hundred part-time
instructors, is assigned to a
patient's home or hospital.

Continuity_
Usually, the teachers are from
the disabled student's current
school so that educational
continuity can be maintained.
In this way children who are
absent from school less than six

weeks at a time are able to
complete their studies while
remaining on the school rolls.
Those who miss more than six
weeks are transferred to the
Home teaching attendence
registers.
SCAP
Although only a few weeks
old, CHIP is expanding daily as
parents discover that their infirm
children, once somewhat
neglected, are eligible to receive
assistance.
Under the same aegis as CHIP
is the Sickle Cell Anemia
Program (SCAP), supervised by
Priscilla Hawkins.
SCAP, funded by a $50,000
federal grant awarded in July,
1974, serves approximately 150
sickle cell victims. SCAP operates
in the same manner as CHIP,
sending teachers to homes and
hospitals.
Like sufferers of chronic

illness, those with sickle cell
anemia rarely miss more than six
weeks of school at one stretch,
although their attendance is
sporadic throughout the
academic year. According to
Bateson, children with the
disease are sometimes less mature
and slower to develop than their
classmates, and, for this reason,
need the attention that SCAP
provides.
'Additional Aid
This year, SCAP was Oven an
additional $21,000 by the federal
government, most of which will
be used to enlarge the staff and
establish sickle cell workshops.

Upon reading the two
editorials in the September 16

year? every two years? every
four? Can we believe the results

those future students do not
possess those morals? Does the
Ethics Code then become
"ekcessively permanent?"

the Honor Code should be
insulted at the thought of
needing protection from "the
temptations and results of a poor
academic atmosphere." However,

change along with the changing

unique in so many ways." I vote
for preserving the Honor Code,
and insulting those who do cheat
by improving the "poor academic
atmosphere" by requiring
personal integrity along with
academic competence.

By DAVID SIEGMAN
Writing about Eric Clapton, I
can't help but mention a fiasco
that I was involved in last
summer. "Liberty Jam '75" was
scheduled to take place at
Memorial Stadium, featuring the
Pure Prairie League, Carlos
Santana, and Eric Clapton.
Residents of the neighborhoods
surrounding the stadium feared
that the throngs of youth
converging on them might
damage and litter their property,
so they brought the matter to
court seeking to have the concert
cancelled. The case floundered in
legal argot for several weeks and
a fiery argument ensued among
the lawyers as to whether Eric
Clapton played "acid rock"
music or country music. One of
the neighborhood leaders
revealed to the press that he
himself had played in a band
specializing in Bill Haley and the
Comets music, and could surely
affirm that the music Eric
Clapton played was acid rock.
Not too long after that the court
decided to back the promoters
and the show was to take place as
announced.
I took off work on July 3, the
day of the concert, and treked
down to the stadium in the early
Morning hours. Seeing Clapton
pull up in a taxi that morning in
a t-shirt and Schlitz sun visor gave
me strength. However, five hours
later, just before the concert was
to have begun, the sky grew dark
and grey. One hell of a storm
passed over the area with
tremendous gusts of wind. The

sound system was knocked out in
seconds. It announced that the
concert was cancelled, and after a
little shouting, a little
bottle-throwing, and a lot of
cursing, thousands of disgruntled
fans were turned away from the
stadium gates to head home
$8.50 poorer. To those of you
still awaiting your refunds,
rejoice in the fact that Clapton's
new live album "E.C. Was Here,"
has just been released. "It's the
next best thing to being there."
Goofed
After reading several reviews
of the album, I borrowed it from
a friend. As I listened, something
bothered me. Two tracks later I
knew what it was. That feeling of
deja vu which always proceeds
the all-too-familiar realization
that they goofed, was in the air.
They blew it! Those insensitive
goggly-eyed ghouls from Rolling
Stone muffed it again. "...The
classic Clapton album;" they had
said. Well, I certainly wouldn't
take it that far. "E.C. Was Here"
is not Clapton's Magnum opus.
His music with Derek and the
Dominoes is in many ways
superior to this album, although
the musical genre there is closer
to rock than blues. On the
"Layla" album for instance,
Clapton's compositional and
singing talents reach full flower,
and with brilliant slide and
second lead guitar from Duane
Allman..., well that's a tough
combination to beat. With the
exception of a splendid version
Df "Rambling on My Mind"(the
first recorded lead vocal by

Clapton from his John Mayall
days) the innovative high
intensity jamming 'of Cream is
more stimulating than the
jamming on "E.C..." The
jamming on the new album is still
strong enough, though, to rivet
one's attention through long
musical progressions.
Well polished
The band presently backing
Clapton is excellent—maybe the
tightest Clapton has played with
so far. Yvonne Elliman, who also
displayed her talents in the
Broadway hit "Jesus Christ
Superstar," has a polished voice
that is extremely well-suited for
duets with Clapton. One of ,the
major let-downs of -"E.C..." is
that so little is heard from
Elliman, the unsung heroine of
the band. George Terry, who
plays the second guitar on the
album, knows where he belongs
on stage, and plays his role to
perfection without straying too
far at any time. Dick Sims-organ,
Jamie Oldaker—drums, and the
unsinkable Carl Radle—bass,
comprise the rest of a very
relaxed band. This faceless group
of musicians play as a single unit
with no individual trying to steal
the show. Clapton has
maintained his versatility with
this band—even broadened it.
From blues to reggae, to R.&B.,
to mainstream rock n' roll, this
band handles its music with the
poise, unpretentiousness, and
non-theatrical form that are
Clapton's trademarks.
One would be remiss in
labeling "E.C..." as "a return to

the strict blues form," as does
Rolling Stone, without observing
certain nuances, and even
obvious changes, in Clapton's
style of blues-playing. Well,
pardon the heresy, but the
failure of the Gospel according to
Rolling Stone to discern
important distinctions is
perplexing. The rigid structure of
Clapton's natal blues-work has
been reshaped. From the speed
riffs in "Have 'You Even Loved a
Woman," which could make
Alvin Lee blush, to the crisp
acoustic lead in "Drifting Blues,"
one notices a fresh accent. The
novel Clapton-Elliman duet on
"Presence of the Lord,"
highlighted by a sudden break in
the music as they harmonize on
the verse "Everybody knows the
secret...," also has no ancestry.
However, the up-tempo break on
the Blind Faith version of the
song is more arousing than this
one.
Best?
Eric Clapton has come full
circle musically. "E.C..." has a
very lucid message: Eric Clapton
is a blues guitarist first and
foremost. The influence of Blind
Faith, Delaney and Bonnie,
Derek and the Dominoes, and
others is visible on "E.C..." But
Clapton sings the blues from the
same torn heart and with the
same genuine feeling.
"E.C. Was Here" is not
Clapton's best album to date, but
if you like either Clapton or
blues, and the two are often
synonymous you'd do well to
get it.

receiving an expanded program
of home and hospital teaching
during their absence from school.
The Chronic Health Impaired
Program (CHIP), directed by
Frances Bateson and Mrs. Nancy
Rini, serves local grade school
students who suffer from
ailments such as diabetes,
asthma, and heart disorders.
Assistance
Previously, only children who
were absent from school for six
weeks or more were eligible for
educational assistance in the
home or hospital. Those with
errant health problems often
missed a substantial portion of
the school year, though each
illness was not long enough to
qualify the student for home
teaching.

CHIP, which started this
month, was conceived by the
Area for Exceptional Children, a
division of the Baltimore City
Public Schools. Financed by local
educational funds, the program is
open to those who attend both
public and private facilities. The
sole stipulation is that the child's
parents reside in Baltimore.
Students with chronic illnesses
are referred to CHIP by health
agencies, hospitals, and
pediatricians.
The staff of 28 qualified
teachers, in addition to a pool of
two hundred part-time
instructors, is assigned to a
patient's home or hospital.

Continuity_
Usually, the teachers are from
the disabled student's current
school so that educational
continuity can be maintained.
In this way children who are
absent from school less than six

weeks at a time are able to
complete their studies while
remaining on the school rolls.
Those who miss more than six
weeks are transferred to the
Home teaching attendence
registers.
SCAP
Although only a few weeks
old, CHIP is expanding daily as
parents discover that their infirm
children, once somewhat
neglected, are eligible to receive
assistance.
Under the same aegis as CHIP
is the Sickle Cell Anemia
Program (SCAP), supervised by
Priscilla Hawkins.
SCAP, funded by a $50,000
federal grant awarded in July,
1974, serves approximately 150
sickle cell victims. SCAP operates
in the same manner as CHIP,
sending teachers to homes and
hospitals.
Like sufferers of chronic

illness, those with sickle cell
anemia rarely miss more than six
weeks of school at one stretch,
although their attendance is
sporadic throughout the
academic year. According to
Bateson, children with the
disease are sometimes less mature
and slower to develop than their
classmates, and, for this reason,
need the attention that SCAP
provides.

This year, SCAP was Oven an
additional $21,000 by the federal
government, most of which will
be used to enlarge the staff and
establish sickle cell workshops.

personal integrity along with
academic competence.

Telephone is threatening the

scenario:

remember it.. Colleges and

By DAVID SIEGMAN
Writing about Eric Clapton, I
can't help but mention a fiasco
that I was involved in last
summer. "Liberty Jam '75" was
scheduled to take place at
Memorial Stadium, featuring the
Pure Prairie League, Carlos
Santana, and Eric Clapton.
Residents of the neighborhoods
surrounding the stadium feared
that the throngs of youth
converging on them might
damage and litter their property,
so they brought the matter to
court seeking to have the concert
cancelled. The case floundered in
legal argot for several weeks and
a fiery argument ensued among
the lawyers as to whether Eric
Clapton played "acid rock"
music or country music. One of
the neighborhood leaders
revealed to the press that he
himself had played in a band
specializing in Bill Haley and the
Comets music, and could surely
affirm that the music Eric
Clapton played was acid rock.
Not too long after that the court
decided to back the promoters
and the show was to take place as
announced.
I took off work on July 3, the
day of the concert, and treked
down to the stadium in the early
Morning hours. Seeing Clapton
pull up in a taxi that morning in
a t-shirt and Schlitz sun visor gave
me strength. However, five hours
later, just before the concert was
to have begun, the sky grew dark
and grey. One hell of a storm
passed over the area with
tremendous gusts of wind. The

sound system was knocked out in
seconds. It announced that the
concert was cancelled, and after a
little shouting, a little
bottle-throwing, and a lot of
cursing, thousands of disgruntled
fans were turned away from the
stadium gates to head home
$8.50 poorer. To those of you
still awaiting your refunds,
rejoice in the fact that Clapton's
new live album "E.C. Was Here,"
has just been released. "It's the
next best thing to being there."
Goofed
After reading several reviews
of the album, I borrowed it from
a friend. As I listened, something
bothered me. Two tracks later I
knew what it was. That feeling of
deja vu which always proceeds
the all-too-familiar realization
that they goofed, was in the air.
They blew it! Those insensitive
goggly-eyed ghouls from Rolling
Stone muffed it again. "...The
classic Clapton album;" they had
said. Well, I certainly wouldn't
take it that far. "E.C. Was Here"
is not Clapton's Magnum opus.
His music with Derek and the
Dominoes is in many ways
superior to this album, although
the musical genre there is closer
to rock than blues. On the
"Layla" album for instance,
Clapton's compositional and
singing talents reach full flower,
and with brilliant slide and
second lead guitar from Duane
Allman..., well that's a tough
combination to beat. With the
exception of a splendid version
Df "Rambling on My Mind"(the
first recorded lead vocal by

Clapton from his John Mayall
days) the innovative high
intensity jamming 'of Cream is
more stimulating than the
jamming on "E.C..." The
jamming on the new album is still
strong enough, though, to rivet
one's attention through long
musical progressions.
Well polished
The band presently backing
Clapton is excellent—maybe the
tightest Clapton has played with
so far. Yvonne Elliman, who also
displayed her talents in the
Broadway hit "Jesus Christ
Superstar," has a polished voice
that is extremely well-suited for
duets with Clapton. One of ,the
major let-downs of -"E.C..." is
that so little is heard from
Elliman, the unsung heroine of
the band. George Terry, who
plays the second guitar on the
album, knows where he belongs
on stage, and plays his role to
perfection without straying too
far at any time. Dick Sims-organ,
Jamie Oldaker—drums, and the
unsinkable Carl Radle—bass,
comprise the rest of a very
relaxed band. This faceless group
of musicians play as a single unit
with no individual trying to steal
the show. Clapton has
maintained his versatility with
this band—even broadened it.
From blues to reggae, to R.&B.,
to mainstream rock n' roll, this
band handles its music with the
poise, unpretentiousness, and
non-theatrical form that are
Clapton's trademarks.
One would be remiss in
labeling "E.C..." as "a return to

the strict blues form," as does
Rolling Stone, without observing
certain nuances, and even
obvious changes, in Clapton's
style of blues-playing. Well,
pardon the heresy, but the
failure of the Gospel according to
Rolling Stone to discern
important distinctions is
perplexing. The rigid structure of
Clapton's natal blues-work has
been reshaped. From the speed
riffs in "Have 'You Even Loved a
Woman," which could make
Alvin Lee blush, to the crisp
acoustic lead in "Drifting Blues,"
one notices a fresh accent. The
novel Clapton-Elliman duet on
"Presence of the Lord,"
highlighted by a sudden break in
the music as they harmonize on
the verse "Everybody knows the
secret...," also has no ancestry.
However, the up-tempo break on
the Blind Faith version of the
song is more arousing than this
one.
Best?
Eric Clapton has come full
circle musically. "E.C..." has a
very lucid message: Eric Clapton
is a blues guitarist first and
foremost. The influence of Blind
Faith, Delaney and Bonnie,
Derek and the Dominoes, and
others is visible on "E.C..." But
Clapton sings the blues from the
same torn heart and with the
same genuine feeling.
"E.C. Was Here" is not
Clapton's best album to date, but
if you like either Clapton or
blues, and the two are often
synonymous you'd do well to
get it.

The Blue Jays will play a three

midfielders, four deep backs, and

give the midfielders a much larger
role in the scoring attack.
Saturday's opening line-up will
see Greg Bradley in goal while

rounding out the defense.
